text: Apologies, I know this has been discussed before, but I'm searching through the slack and I can't find what I'm looking for. I'm backtesting a strategy that is putting up offers and am pleased with the results. Since this is my first attempt at offering prices I am keen to understand how the flumine backtest might translate into real life betting. I'd really appreciate anyone's insight into how I might expect my strategy to translate from backtest to real life. Ultimately I will run this strategy live either way and find out for myself!

text: <@U026A3LU7TN> has joined the channel

<@U0155J92A7Q> You can't strictly make the assumption that they're independent, since the act of placing the first bet impacts the market for the 2nd. And backtesting won't have taken this into account. That said, unless your bets are big relative to the market, I'd do it any way. A number of people here run Monte Carlo simulations to understand the range of potential outcomes, even wen they're clearly +EV. I load the data into a Pandas dataframe and draw tens of thousands of samples and although that is computationally intensive, it really doesn't take very long to run (a minute or two).

elements.text: You can't strictly make the assumption that they're independent, since the act of placing the first bet impacts the market for the 2nd. And backtesting won't have taken this into account. That said, unless your bets are big relative to the market, I'd do it any way. A number of people here run Monte Carlo simulations to understand the range of potential outcomes, even wen they're clearly +EV. I load the data into a Pandas dataframe and draw tens of thousands of samples and although that is computationally intensive, it really doesn't take very long to run (a minute or two).

text:
As a general point not specifically addressing <@U0155J92A7Q> or <@U01LD279D16> - I think people often don't ask the right questions with regard to this sort of thing, or else they ask them for the wrong reasons. The best predictor of the success of a strategy is very likely the person who designed it. How successful is strategy X likely to be? How successful is strategy Y (designed by <@UBS7QANF3>) likely to be? If you've got a bit of sense you apply that logic to yourself.

In any case why do you want to know? So that you can fantasize? Always a bad idea. So that you can scale before your returns justify it? Always a bad idea.

Of course back-testing can be an important part of design and development but it's usually a mistake to look to it for confidence or money management.

text:
As someone who started less then a year ago, so relatively new, I always assume that any strategy I design will fail when it goes live! It helps to have realistic expectations.

<@UGV299K6H> as someone with a lot of experience what is your success rate like for new strategies you design? Do the majority of them succeed or is it closer to 50/50?

elements.text: As someone who started less then a year ago, so relatively new, I always assume that any strategy I design will fail when it goes live! It helps to have realistic expectations.
as someone with a lot of experience what is your success rate like for new strategies you design? Do the majority of them succeed or is it closer to 50/50?

text:
The notion of a 'strategy' isn't usually that applicable to me because most of the time I'm just adding some new bit of insight into my primary operation so the better question might be: How frequently do my changes improve results? I guess that's about 75% of the time but it's hard to say because there's a lot of feeling around for an optimum.

I do try completely new things and if I get as far as betting on them they always make profits but they're not always as good as I hoped for. Assuming something works well I take the learning from it and absorb that into my main operation so I don't have an accumulation of strategies on one sport.

I think <@UGV299K6H> has a good point here, I have previously stated that live tends to be better in terms of matching/pnl compared to backtesting but that is probably because I know the limitations / logic extremely well. You only need to be pushing the simulation logic slightly too far to then get contradicting returns when live.

Maybe we can add some warnings into the logic when limitations might be breached.

has a good point here, I have previously stated that live tends to be better in terms of matching/pnl compared to backtesting but that is probably because I know the limitations / logic extremely well. text:
Some things that will introduce discrepancies between a back test and live results:

1. Betting too frequently on a selection such that you are double counting available liquidity 
2. Competing with others for the same bet (will come down to if one of you has a consistent speed edge)
3. Trying to take liquidity that is fleeting (similar to the previous point but you’re trying to beat someone else’s cancel)
4. Leaving orders up
5. Wiping out the order book
If you don’t do any of these things it is possible to achieve perfect agreement between backtest and live or at least have discrepancies of a few pennies

elements.text: Some things that will introduce discrepancies between a back test and live results:
Betting too frequently on a selection such that you are double counting available liquidity
Competing with others for the same bet (will come down to if one of you has a consistent speed edge)
Trying to take liquidity that is fleeting (similar to the previous point but you’re trying to beat someone else’s cancel)
Leaving orders up
Wiping out the order book
If you don’t do any of these things it is possible to achieve perfect agreement between backtest and live or at least have discrepancies of a few pennies

text: My personal experience has been that live betting P&L is significantly _better_ than Flumine backtests, i.e. one particular strategy has been matching a lot more bets than the backtests suggested. IMO the _type_ of strategy makes a difference.

elements.text: My personal experience has been that live betting P&L is significantly
better
than Flumine backtests, i.e. one particular strategy has been matching a lot more bets than the backtests suggested. IMO the
type
of strategy makes a difference.

text:
I'm not saying it's not useful, just that I think you have to ask yourself what you're hoping to get from it and that I think forecasting your profits is a poor application. It's better applied to (say) the optimisation of execution prices, in which case you're comparing back-test to back-test and the comparison between real and simulated results doesn't really arise.

Certainly the type of strategy will make a difference to how simulated and real results compare but even if the simulated matching was perfect it and couldn't possibly accommodate your effect on the market. Every participant alters the market and the more you're betting the bigger your effect. Although overfitting is a separate issue it's worth remembering that even a perfect matching simulation will do absolutely nothing to help you with that. For most newer players the over-fitting errors are likely to eclipse anything to do with simulated matching.

text: It's difficult to build a good general purpose backtest framework. Flumine does a decent job but as a general purpose backtester it cannot make assumptions that a specific backtester could make in order to better simulate reality.

elements.text: It's difficult to build a good general purpose backtest framework. Flumine does a decent job but as a general purpose backtester it cannot make assumptions that a specific backtester could make in order to better simulate reality.

text: For example, suppose you have a strategy that bets on BSP, some time before the off. Suppose you also have some knowledge as to how presence of pending BSP orders impact the eventual uncrossing price. You can factor this logic into how the BSP uncrossing goes. Flumine on the other hand would not consider this market impact (nor should it as a general framework).

elements.text: For example, suppose you have a strategy that bets on BSP, some time before the off. text: <@U01PJ5YMFBJ>, why 30s? It seems like an arbitary number with no real significance. You always need to be mindful of backfitting, in any data you'll find a magic number that somehow 'works' but it won't tell you anything about the future. If the 30s varied dependant on some other concrete market data, time/vol/activity level or whatever then it might aquire some validity.  I think you know that though. There's a lot to think about, try to slow it down just a bit and re-read your notebook before making decisions or assumptions. Personally if I have an idea in 5mins I'll spend the next 55 trying to prove it's no good or flawed, you need to be the meanest manager you've ever given work to.  And making mistakes is fine but making the same mistake twice should really result in giving yourself a written warning.:grinning:
